src:
Mitin en Vitoria
Casado: "Sánchez se ha quitado la careta y volverá a llevar a un bloqueo"
Según el líder del PP :"Quien no quiera que Torra, Junqueras y Otegi manden en España tiene que votar al PP"
01 Nov 2019, 14:09 by Efe
El líder del PP, Pablo Casado, ha considerado que el jefe del Ejecutivo en funciones, Pedro Sánchez, se ha "quitado la careta" coincidiendo con la celebración de Halloween y ha reconocido que "otra vez va a llevar a un bloqueo" porque quiere volver a reeditar "un Gobierno Frankestein".
En un acto electoral en un hotel de Vitoria, ha criticado de esta manera la intervención de Sánchez en esta misma ciudad, donde ha descartado un gran pacto con el PP y ha instado al líder de Podemos, Pablo Iglesias, a decir si impedirá de nuevo un Gobierno socialista.
Para Casado esto supone que Sánchez "después de varias semanas mostrando su truco, hoy ha mostrado su trato" y ha dejado claro que quiere volver a "disfrazarse de Frankenstein" porque pretende volver a pactar con Unidas Podemos y los independentistas.
Por eso, el líder de los populares ha instado a que "quien no quiera que Torra, Junqueras y Otegi manden en España tiene que votar al PP".
A su juicio, Sánchez ya ha reconocido este viernes que "va perdiendo el referéndum" sobre su continuidad en La Moncloa que son estas elecciones y ha reprochado al candidato socialista incluso su forma "desabrida" de exigir un posicionamiento a Iglesias.
"¿Qué cree que es la democracia?, ¿qué quiere? ¿que lo hagamos santo súbito?, ¿que lo que hagamos sea coronarle rey de España? Ya sabemos lo que le gustan los besamanos", ha ironizado sobre las pretensiones de Sánchez.
También ha tratado de "cínico" al presidente del Gobierno en funciones por ofrecerse a acoger en Madrid la celebración de la cumbre por el clima, tras la renuncia de Chile, cuando "no sabe garantizar la seguridad" de un partido FC Barcelona-Real Madrid.
"Haga usted los deberes en Barcelona y deje de dar lecciones en Chile", le ha espetado a Sánchez, en un mitin en el que ha endurecido su tono contra el candidato socialista y ha vuelto a situarse como la única alternativa a un nuevo Gobierno socialista.

text:
Meeting in Vitoria
Married: "Sánchez has taken off his mask and will lead to a blockade"
According to the leader of the PP: "Who does not want Torra, Junqueras and Otegi to send in Spain has to vote for the PP"
01 Nov 2019, 14:09 by Efe
The leader of the PP, Pablo Casado, has considered that the head of the acting Executive, Pedro Sánchez, has "taken off his mask" coinciding with the celebration of Halloween and has acknowledged that "again it will lead to a blockade" because he wants reissue "a Frankestein Government".
In an electoral act in a hotel in Vitoria, he has criticized Sanchez's intervention in this same city, where he has ruled out a great pact with the PP and urged the leader of Podemos, Pablo Iglesias, to say if he will prevent again a socialist government.
For Casado this means that Sanchez "after several weeks showing his trick, today he has shown his treatment" and has made it clear that he wants to return to "disguise himself as Frankenstein" because he intends to reconnect with United Podemos and the independentistas.
Therefore, the leader of the popular has urged that "whoever does not want Torra, Junqueras and Otegi to send in Spain has to vote for the PP".
In his opinion, Sanchez has already acknowledged this Friday that "he is losing the referendum" on his continuity in La Moncloa, which are these elections and has reproached the socialist candidate for even his "poor" way of demanding a position to Iglesias.
"What do you think democracy is? What do you want? That we make it a sudden saint? That what we do is crown you king of Spain? We already know what you like, the kissers", he has ironized about Sánchez's pretensions .
He has also tried to "cynical" to the President of the Government in office for offering to host the climate summit in Madrid, after the resignation of Chile, when "he does not know how to guarantee the safety" of a FC Barcelona-Real Madrid match .
"Do your homework in Barcelona and stop giving lessons in Chile," he snapped to Sanchez, at a rally in which he has hardened his tone against the socialist candidate and has once again positioned himself as the only alternative to a new socialist government. .
